content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and comfort with uncertainty, I would choose to play this game strategically. Since the payoff is higher when both players pick different choices (R or B), it seems like a dominant strategy to consistently pick R in this situation. The chance of having the same outcome (both R or both B) is reduced due to the higher reward for opposite choices. However, I should also consider the possibility that my opponent may be reasoning the same way and choose to switch strategies mid-game to take advantage of this assumption. In such a case, it might be beneficial to alternate between R and B, or even use a mixed strategy like picking R 60% of the time and B 40% of the time. Ultimately, I would pick R as my initial choice (R{}). But throughout the game, I would monitor my opponent's choices for potential adjustments in my own strategy.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Since my initial strategy was to pick R, and my opponent chose B in this round, I will stick with my original strategy for the next round. My hope is that by consistently picking R, I can induce my opponent to switch strategies in their favor, making them vulnerable when they eventually choose R. So, I would choose R again (R{}). It's important to remember that a single game may not provide enough information to determine the optimal strategy for both players. To make a more informed decision, we should observe our opponent's choices and adjust our own accordingly based on their patterns over several rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent has consistently chosen B, it seems like they are following a specific strategy. Given that I know their choice in the previous round and my initial payoff was zero, I should expect a higher payoff if I switch strategies and choose B this time around. Thus, I will change my strategy for the next round and choose B (B{}). This way, I hope to take advantage of their consistency in choosing B and secure a higher payoff for myself in the future rounds. It's essential to remain adaptable and observe our opponent's choices carefully, as they may adjust their strategies based on our own actions.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose R in the previous round, and I got a higher payoff by choosing B, I will stick with that strategy for the next round as well (B{}). However, I must also be prepared for potential changes in their strategy and adapt accordingly. By carefully observing our opponents' choices, we can make more informed decisions and improve our chances of maximizing our payoffs over the course of the game.
